DataElement.preferredDefinition: A synthetic aminoethylamide with local anesthetic and antiarrhythmic properties. Lidocaine stabilizes the neuronal membrane by binding to and inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels, thereby inhibiting the ionic fluxes required for the initiation and conduction of impulses and effecting local anesthesia. An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect. Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot." Given. A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect. Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot." Given.

Concepts.definition: A synthetic aminoethylamide with local anesthetic and antiarrhythmic properties. Lidocaine stabilizes the neuronal membrane by binding to and inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels, thereby inhibiting the ionic fluxes required for the initiation and conduction of impulses and effecting local anesthesia.
An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.
Administration of a drug into a location within the body; this can be achieved either through an established access or via a needle.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
